tit.e: Keiun-kan Guesthouse (a state guesthouse in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture)

sen.j: 慶雲館（けいうんかん）は滋賀県長浜市にある市の迎賓館。
sen.e: Keiun-kan (慶雲館) is the city guest house in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.
Keiun-kan is a state guesthouse in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 明治20年（1887年）に明治天皇行在所として建設された。
sen.e: It was built as Emperor Meiji's Anzaisho (the temporary lodging built to accommodate an imperial visit) in 1887.
It was built as Emperor Meiji's Anzaisho (provisional palace for Emperor's going out) in 1887.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 館名は当時の総理大臣であった伊藤博文の命名と伝わる。
sen.e: It is said that the name of the house was put by the then Prime Minister Hirobumi ITO.
It is said that Hirobumi ITO, Prime Minister at the time named the guesthouse.
It is said that Hirobumi ITO, Prime Minister at the time named the guesthouse.

sen.j: 本庭の池泉回遊式庭園（国指定の名勝）は名匠７代目小川治兵衛の代表作であると同時に近代日本庭園の最高傑作の一つとして名高い。
sen.e: Chisen Kaiyushiki Teien Garden (a fairly large garden form that allows visitors to view the garden while strolling around its pond and fountain and through its premise; this garden has been designated as National Scenic Beauty) of the main garden was a representative work of a master craftsman Jihei OGAWA the seventh, and at the same time it is famous for being one of the supreme masterpieces of the modern Japanese gardens.

sen.j: 毎年1～3月には日本一と賞される長浜盆梅展が開催される。
sen.e: From January to March every year, Nagahama Bonbai (bonsai of Japanese apricot trees) Exhibition which is admired as No. 1 in Japan is held at the house.

sen.j: 大通寺 (長浜市)別殿跡地に長浜の実業家・浅見又蔵が私財を投じて明治天皇行在所として建設したもので、明治20年（1887年）2月21日の朝に竣工。
sen.e: The house was built as Emperor Meiji's Anzaisho with the private money spent by Matazo ASAMI, a business man of Nagahama, at the remained site of the annex hall of Daitsu-ji Temple (Nagahama City), and it was completed on the morning of February 21, 1887

sen.j: 同日、明治天皇と昭憲皇太后が来訪した。
sen.e: On the same day, Emperor Meiji and Empress Dowager Shoken visited this house.

sen.e: 1912: The extensive main garden (Chisen Kaiyushiki Teien Garden) was constructed by Jihei OGAWA.

sen.j: 本館 - 明治20年竣工、総檜造、寄棟造、瓦葺、二階建、書院風建築、2階に玉座、延床面積500m2、建設費１万円（当時）。
sen.e: Main building: Completed in 1887; a two-storied shoin (reception room) style building with so-hinoki-zukuri (built with only a Japanese cypress), yosemune-zukuri (hipped roof), and kawarabuki (tiled roof); the Imperial throne is on the second floor; the total amount of floor space is 500 square meters and the construction cost was 10,000 yen (at the time of the construction).
